metadata.title: Material Analysis Sets: Multi-Era Ceramic Material Chemistry
metadata.description: Historical oxide analyses for ceramic materials across eras, suppliers, and authorities. Each set provides a complete or partial mapping of material IDs to oxide weight-percent analyses. When a set lacks a material, the app falls back to the default set.
metadata.author: Ryan - ConduitBridge / Ceramics Computing

analysis_sets.name: Stull Atlas Default
analysis_sets.notes: Current app defaults. Digitalfire 2024 analyses verified and corrected Feb 2026.

analysis_sets.name: Digitalfire 2024
analysis_sets.notes: Current Digitalfire Reference Library analyses, cross-checked Feb 2026 via MCP. Corrections applied where our stored values diverged from Digitalfire's current published data.

analysis_sets.name: Rhodes (1973)
analysis_sets.source: Clay and Glazes for the Potter, 2nd Ed.
analysis_sets.notes: THE classic reference. Many potters still formulate from these values. Material analyses reflect 1960s-70s mining and supplier data.

analysis_sets.name: Cardew (1969)
analysis_sets.notes: Influential stoneware/wood fire reference. Analyses reflect British and West African raw materials of the era.

analysis_sets.name: Hamer & Hamer (1986)
analysis_sets.source: The Potter's Dictionary of Materials and Techniques
analysis_sets.notes: Comprehensive UK/international reference. Widely used in European ceramics education.

analysis_sets.name: Nelson (1984)
analysis_sets.notes: Standard American university ceramics textbook for decades.

analysis_sets.name: Hesselberth & Roy (2002)
analysis_sets.notes: Modern mid-fire reference. Analyses reflect late 1990s-early 2000s supplier data.

analysis_sets.name: Insight / Foresight (~1995)
analysis_sets.notes: Tony Hansen's original desktop glaze software. These were the standard digital analyses for the pre-web era.
